<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS

9702/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 730, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 126, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>Data</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 104, 599, 121]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 136, 640, 153]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 168, 630, 185]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 200, 630, 217]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 231, 630, 248]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 262, 630, 279]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 293, 650, 310]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 324, 630, 341]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 355, 650, 371]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \text{ J K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 386, 690, 403]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^{2} \text{ kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 416, 655, 433]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \text{ F m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 434, 650, 465]]<|/det|>
\[( \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} = 8.99 \times 10^9 \text{ m F}^{-1} )\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 479, 635, 496]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 510, 688, 527]]<|/det|>
Stefanâ€“Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{ W m}^{-2} \text{ K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 567, 170, 583]]<|/det|>
<form>Formulae</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 600, 560, 616]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 617, 583, 636]]<|/det|>
\[\nu^2 = u^2 + 2as\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 650, 551, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 681, 544, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F = \rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 714, 556, 746]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_0 = \frac{f_s V}{V \pm V_s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 761, 554, 778]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I = \text{Anvq}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 793, 611, 810]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 824, 616, 856]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 322, 87]]<|/det|>
Define acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 131, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
In an experiment, two objects A and B are released from the side of a building, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 203, 787, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 501, 591, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 798, 551]]<|/det|>
Object A is released from rest at a height of \(14\mathrm{m}\) above the horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 918, 581]]<|/det|>
Object B is released with an initial upwards vertical velocity \(u\) at a height of \(3.6\mathrm{m}\) above the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 579, 913, 612]]<|/det|>
Both objects take the same time to reach the ground and they do not collide with each other. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 181, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 625, 663, 644]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken for object A to reach the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[526, 732, 920, 751]]<|/det|>
<form>time = ....................................................... $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 733, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 764, 181, 782]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 764, 524, 782]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (b)(i) to calculate \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 903, 893, 922]]<|/det|>
<form>u = .................................................... $m s^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 904, 920, 922]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 69, 144, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
In a second experiment, object B is released from the same height and given the same initial speed as in (b) but at a release angle \(\theta\) to the vertical, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 112, 591, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 294, 534, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 325, 180, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 325, 918, 359]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the time taken for object B to reach the ground is less than, the same as or greater than the time in (b)(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 432, 918, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 464, 181, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 464, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
By considering energy, state and explain the effect of the change in release angle on the speed at which B reaches the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 603, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 603, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 144, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 415, 88]]<|/det|>
State the principle of moments.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 163, 873, 181]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 146, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
Three objects A, B and C are placed on a horizontal beam. The beam is in equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 235, 806, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 434, 589, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 507, 483]]<|/det|>
The beam is uniform and has length \(6.0 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 489, 497]]<|/det|>
The pivot is at the midpoint of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 616, 513]]<|/det|>
Object A has mass \(60\mathrm{kg}\) and is at one end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 663, 528]]<|/det|>
Object B has mass \(45\mathrm{kg}\) and is at a distance \(x\) from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 663, 544]]<|/det|>
Object C has mass \(80\mathrm{kg}\) and is at the other end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 572, 256, 590]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 743, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ....................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 744, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 529, 88]]<|/det|>
The beam is \(0.80 \text{m}\) above horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Object A is removed and replaced by a spring connected to the ground and the beam, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 144, 892, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 299, 534, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
After the change, the beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium. The positions of B and C are unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 376, 744, 394]]<|/det|>
The spring has an unstretched length of \(0.59 \text{m}\) and obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 180, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 408, 549, 426]]<|/det|>
Calculate the spring constant of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[438, 574, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
<form>spring constant = ............................................... N m\({}^{-1}\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 607, 181, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 607, 613, 625]]<|/det|>
Calculate the elastic potential energy of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 747, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<form>elastic potential energy = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 778, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 143, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 69, 272, 88]]<|/det|>
Define power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 131, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
An electric car is powered by a motor. The car is travelling at a constant speed of \(35 \text{m s}^{-1}\) along a straight horizontal road, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 208, 816, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 388, 532, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 420, 630, 440]]<|/det|>
There is a total resistive force of \(1750 \text{N}\) acting on the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 181, 471]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 451, 767, 470]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power transmitted to the wheels of the car by the motor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 574, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
<form>power = ....................................................W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 606, 181, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 605, 900, 625]]<|/det|>
Calculate the useful work done by the motor when the car travels a distance of \(17\mathrm{km}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 744, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The potential difference (p.d.) across the motor has a constant value of \(600\mathrm{V}\) and the motor has an efficiency of \(85\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 120, 477, 136]]<|/det|>
Calculate the current in the motor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<form>current = .......................................................A [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 148, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 335, 626, 353]]<|/det|>
The car in **(b)** now reaches a slope, as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 361, 816, 508]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 526, 534, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 555, 672, 574]]<|/det|>
The car continues down the slope at the same speed as in **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 587, 576, 604]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, of the slope on:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 619, 185, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 619, 480, 636]]<|/det|>
the air resistance acting on the car

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 680, 920, 699]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 711, 181, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 711, 393, 728]]<|/det|>
the current in the motor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 803, 920, 822]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 69, 143, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 69, 448, 88]]<|/det|>
State the principle of superposition.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 163, 870, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 900, 214]]<|/det|>
Light of wavelength \(7.2 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}\) is incident normally on a double slit, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 222, 855, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 443, 591, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 489, 903, 508]]<|/det|>
A screen is at a distance \(D\) from the double slit. The double slit and the screen are parallel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 520, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
The separation of the slits in the double-slit arrangement is \(0.16 \text{mm}\). The resulting interference pattern on the screen contains nine dark fringes, as shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 564, 803, 752]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 766, 591, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 789, 88]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centres of the first and ninth dark fringes is \(3.2 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 183, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 102, 299, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 271, 920, 290]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
The slit separation is now gradually decreased from \(0.16 \text{mm}\) to \(0.04 \text{mm}\). The distance between the centres of adjacent dark fringes is \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 655, 369]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.3, sketch the variation of \(x\) with slit separation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 377, 752, 700]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 715, 534, 733]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 732, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 763, 920, 781]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 141, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 888, 89]]<|/det|>
Use the definitions of speed \(v\), frequency \(f\) and wavelength \(\lambda\) to derive the wave equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 116, 527, 134]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = f\lambda .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 303, 922, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 908, 353]]<|/det|>
A source of sound waves of frequency \(236\mathrm{Hz}\) is travelling at a constant velocity of \(20\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
A stationary observer has a microphone connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO). The microphone detects the sound waves as the source moves directly towards the observer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 584, 429]]<|/det|>
The resulting trace on the CRO is shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 438, 744, 728]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 747, 534, 766]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 778, 556, 797]]<|/det|>
The time-base on the CRO is set to \(1.0 \text{ms} \text{div}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 796, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculate the frequency of the sound waves detected by the microphone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 211, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 240, 180, 258]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 240, 527, 258]]<|/det|>
Determine the speed of the sound in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 427, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<form>speed of sound = ................................................. m s\(^{- 1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 458, 920, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 143, 94]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 120]]<|/det|> Nitrogen-12 ( \(^{12}_{7}\mathrm {N})\) is an unstable isotope of nitrogen that decays by the emission of radiation to carbon-12 ( \(^{12}_{6}\mathrm {C}\) ). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 843, 149]]<|/det|> Complete the full nuclear equation for the decay, including all the particles involved. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 186, 255, 210]]<|/det|> \[^{12}_{7}\mathrm {N}\rightarrow\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 222, 920, 241]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 146, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 252, 920, 288]]<|/det|> Hydrogen-1 ( \(^{1}_{1}\mathrm {H})\) is an isotope of hydrogen. An atom of hydrogen-1 comprises a proton with an orbiting electron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 300, 920, 335]]<|/det|> An antiparticle equivalent of hydrogen-1 comprises an antiproton with an orbiting positron. The antiquarks in the antiproton are the antiparticles of the quarks in a proton. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 180, 366]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 346, 764, 366]]<|/det|> State the charge on the positron in terms of the elementary charge e. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 408, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
